citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The Program of Vet Care does not include a plan for routine sampling of fecal matter for intestinal parasites. Intestinal
parasites may cause weight loss, low red blood cell count, diarrhea, or may even be without symptoms. A microscopic
exam of fecal matter is used to screen for underlying intestinal parasites. Licensee to correct by ensuring they establish
and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care by using the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and
treat diseases. Correct by February 10, 2024, onward.

There are two adult dogs not up to date on the required distemper/parvovirus (DAPP) vaccines. “Rusty”, a male red
Poodle, was last vaccinated for DAPP on 10/22, due on 10/23. “Jewel”, a female Havanese has no record of receiving the
DAPP vaccine. Distemper and parvovirus are viruses that can cause infected dogs stress, discomfort, pain, or even
death. It is important for breeding females to receive proper vaccinations because they will transfer immunity to their
offspring.
The facility has not had any fecal samples tested for the year. Numerous contagious intestinal parasites can be passed
via the stool, causing weight loss, diarrhea, low red blood cell count, and other unhealthy conditions. A routine
preventative fecal sampling plan can help identify and treat any potential underlying parasitic conditions.
Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases and sampling and treatment of parasites must be performed in
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by: Feb 10, 2024, onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The Program of Vet Care does not include a plan for routine sampling of fecal matter for intestinal parasites. Intestinal 
parasites may cause weight loss, low red blood cell count, diarrhea, or may even be without symptoms. A microscopic 
exam of fecal matter is used to screen for underlying intestinal parasites. Licensee to correct by ensuring they establish 
and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care by using the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and 
treat diseases. Correct by February 10, 2024, onward. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There are two adult dogs not up to date on the required distemper/parvovirus (DAPP) vaccines. “Rusty”, a male red 
Poodle, was last vaccinated for DAPP on 10/22, due on 10/23. “Jewel”, a female Havanese has no record of receiving the 
DAPP vaccine. Distemper and parvovirus are viruses that can cause infected dogs stress, discomfort, pain, or even 
death. It is important for breeding females to receive proper vaccinations because they will transfer immunity to their 
offspring.  
 
The facility has not had any fecal samples tested for the year. Numerous contagious intestinal parasites can be passed 
via the stool, causing weight loss, diarrhea, low red blood cell count, and other unhealthy conditions. A routine 
preventative fecal sampling plan can help identify and treat any potential underlying parasitic conditions. 
 
Vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases and sampling and treatment of parasites must be performed in 
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by: Feb 10, 2024, onward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
